title: Between 1 April 2017 and 31 March 2018, will an armed group from Turkey engage in a campaign that systematically kills 1,000 or more civilians in Turkey?
preds: Turkey has a small and important piece of land in Europe, but functions as a middle-eastern state.  Human rights violations are common, including suppressing the media.  Turkey has very significant geopolitical value to just about every major world power.  My current concern is the battle in Raqqa, which boosted the arms caches of the Kurds.  Turkey is protesting the move to anyone who will listen, but Russia, USA and Syria believe taking the ISIS stronghold of Raqqa is more important than Turkish protests of the method of conquest.  The Kurdish people occupy parts of Turkey and would be considered a group within Turkey, but in my opinion, the Kurds have enough military savvy to protect themselves.  I believe no armed group from within Turkey will systematically kill 1,000 or more civilians in Turkey by April 1, 2018.

Our base rates could be this kind of events in Russia, Turkey, Iran, Syria, Ukraine, Greece, Armenia, Georgia, Lebanon, the Balkans since 1960. I guess this would give a base rate of 1% per country per year. The only cases I come to think of that could qualify is present Syria and the Balkan wars.  We can adjust upwards for Turkey, due to recent political change and neighbouring war and Kurd-conflict. Though not by that much. A cumulative of cirka 2000 died in the kurd-conflict last year. Kurd-violence seems unlikely the conflict has gone on for 30+ years. Nothing like this has happened. Let us say 1% risk of Kurd-violence.  We have a recent major change in Turkey and neighboring wars, which should get to adjust the basis upwards. By how much? Not super much. Turkey saw about four coups since 1930, none had qualifying killings. We might double the cumulative base rate to 4%. Another thing: the wording is broad. Say there is a huge drought in Kurdistan. If Erdogan knowingly does not help, and by negligance causes 1000 to starve to death that would count. With the open wording I do not want to go lower than 4%. 1000+ active killing of civilians would be enormously harmful to the regime. The West does not look kindly at that. Turkey benefits from being a Western ally against Russia and Arabs. I do not see violence against Kurds as a wise move for Erdogan. They are not going to depose him. Facts I used as basis: Base rate? In 1960 Turkey had a coup. Barely anyone was killed. 1976-1980 they had a period of political violence 5000 died in 4 years. Concerning the coup of 1971 "the National Intelligence Organization (MİT) used the Ziverbey Villa as a torture center, employing physical and psychological coercion.[13]" "According to the anti-fascist Searchlight magazine, in 1978 there were 3,319 fascist attacks, in which 831 were killed and 3,121 wounded.[10] In the central trial against the left-wing organization Devrimci Yol (Revolutionary Path) at Ankara Military Court the defendants listed 5,388 political killings before the military coup. " In the many coups of Turkey we have not seen anything that would qualify. The Turkish situation seems grim. We can assume it is comparable to the other coups. Consider the following; "According to Amnesty International, detainees in Turkey have been denied access to legal counsel, have been beaten and tortured, and have not been provided with adequate food, water, or medical care, in the aftermath of the failed coup." Wikipedia A purge has seen over 45,000 military officials, police officers, judges, governors and civil servants arrested or suspended, including 2,700 judges, 15,000 teachers, and every university dean in the country.[16] 163 generals and admirals were detained, around 45% of the Turkish military's total.[19] The sheer number of these arrests made at such a speed could only be done so if the "Turkish government had all those lists ready", as suggested by Johannes Hahn, European Commissioner for Enlargement and European Neighbourhood Policy, on 18 July 2016. Hahn also claimed that because these lists were already available immediately after the coup, the "event was prepared" and the lists were to be used "at a certain stage".[20] Turkey's media purge after the coup d'état attempt resulted in the shutdown of at least 131 media outlets[17] and the arrest of 117 journalists[21] – at least 35 of whom have been indicted for "membership in a terror group" "  Wikipedia
With Erdogan's new mandate he may push harder against the kurds.

Flush with victory, Erdoigan may wish to relax after his labours by killing some more Kurds.  A thousand is a lot, but he's a hard-working guy.  He will deny that any of his vics were civilians, so the resolution of this, as with several others, may depend on whose information is relied on.

Turkey has multiple potential conflicts. Kurds obviously can flare with 1k+ casualties. It is certainly a possibility that isn't extremely unlikely.  ISIS and rebels from Syria might somehow flare inside Turkey borders. Even with Turkey's strenght and the main conflict being outside Turkish territory, it is not 0.00 probability for such to happen.  My guess gives Kurds 10% to flare, and ISIS+Syrians 2%. Remember that ISIS can come from Iraq as well.

There are multiple paths here, including a Kurdish revolt (either spillover from Iraq or in retaliation against Erdogan), spillover from Syria, and a major crackdown against urban protests. I'm probably a bit high on this estimate but this is definitely a case to worry about.

Erdogan would have been a very sore loser.  He may well also prove to be a sore winner, and go back to sending some folks around to bomb Kurdistan in order to protect democracy.  I wish I could go lower on this one, but I'm afraid I should probably go higher.  I'll hold off on this for a while to see how he behaves, though.
If Erdogan wins the referendum he could go back to killing Kurds.  This could also happen if he loses.  He needs a new hobby.

Just realized I was using cumulative totals instead of yearly totals. After a few quiet years, in 2015 and 2016 casualty numbers have shot up and I think there is a small chance that 2017 also tops 1,000.
I am worried that the Kurdish situation is only getting worse and that as part of consolidating his power, Erdogan may choose to target the Kurds as a way of building his support.
This is a tough one because of the phrasing. I think the Kurds are a possible target for this type of event to happen, but I'm not sure it will happen within Turkey's borders.
Elevated risk because of continuing civil war in Kurdish regions.
Erdogan is seizing total power and increasingly cracking down on the Kurds.  I foresee genocidal killing of Kurds in the near future.
The military won't let it happen.
Erdogan is using the Kurdish conflict to grab more power. He has killed and jailed many Kurds, but 1,000 over the next year seems a bit too much
Big number to reach, still the Erdogan crowd are capable of anything, and cover-ups now in Turkey are the  norm, as an emerging allied of Putin, Erdogan is learning the Ruskyos ways.
Erdogan is unlikely to do anything himself; however ISIS may spring up elsewhere given a chance like this bad government

Turkey's Erdogan says he's 'guardian of peace,' as seeks Kurds' support Sezer (2017) Sat Apr 1, states that: President Tayyip Erdogan described himself as a "guardian of peace" on Saturday as he called on Kurds in conflict-torn southeast Turkey to vote 'yes' in a referendum in two weeks’ time on reforms that would grant him sweeping new powers. Since the collapse of a two-year-old ceasefire in July 2015, the mainly Kurdish southeast has been rocked by some of the most intense fighting in three decades of conflict between Kurdish militants and Turkish security forces. According to a United Nations estimate, about 2,000 people were killed and up to a half a million displaced in the state's conflict with Kurdistan Workers Party (PKK) militants. The pro-Kurdish Peoples' Democratic Party (HDP), strongly supported in the southeast but cast by Erdogan as an extension of the PKK, was among the targets of the president's ire during a rallying speech in the region's largest city Diyarbakir. "These supporters of the PKK keep on saying 'peace, peace, peace'. Does empty talk bring peace? Could there be peace with those who walk around with weapons in their hands?" he said. "We are the guardians of peace, we are the guardians of freedoms," he said as a crowd of several thousand in the city centre waved Turkish flags. "WALK TOGETHER" The ruling AK Party, which Erdogan founded, also has strong support in the southeast. In a close race, pollsters say Kurdish voters, about a fifth of the electorate, could tip the balance in the April 16 referendum (para. 1-7). Sezer, M. (2017). Turkey's Erdogan says he's 'guardian of peace,' as seeks Kurds' support. Reuters. World News. Retrieved from
http://uk.reuters.com/article/uk-turkey-referendum-idUKKBN1733PN

The question set-up makes it difficult to resolve as yes. From 1984 to 2015 approximately 7000 civilians have been killed in the Turkey-Kurdish conflict, which makes roughly  225/year http://www.yenisafak.com/en/news/nearly-7000-civilians-killed-by-pkk-in-31-years-2237092. There were 300 casualties in the failed coup attempt last year, of which 47 were civillians http://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/turkey-coup-dead-erdogan-military-chief-ankara-istanbul-death-toll-plotters-how-many-killed-wounded-a7140376.html. Even with the passing of the referendum and the further escalation it may cause, 1000 casualties is unlikely to be reached.

likely. but not most likely. armed conflict is never a distant option when it comes to middle east scnearios. Turkey designed to be an integral part of Europe. however, the people chose to be part of middle east. that has a toll to pay. so the armed conflict shall be triggered after the elections to be held, or, after/during the economic crisis that seems to be brewing right now.
The Government will blame the Kurds
